item.title: namaha
item.dc:creator: anna_project3

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: anna_project3
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Suggested text: Our website address is: http://localhost/project3.

Comments

Suggested text: When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

Suggested text: If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Cookies

Suggested text: If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Suggested text: Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Who we share your data with

Suggested text: If you request a password reset, your IP address will be included in the reset email.

How long we retain your data

Suggested text: If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

Suggested text: If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Suggested text: Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

item.title: Welcome
item.dc:creator: anna_project3
item.content:encoded:
Welcome!

The mission of the Alabama Institute for Mindfulness (AIM) is to promote mindfulness to a public struggling with the impact of stress on wellness and daily living by helping individuals access their inner resources and cultivate resilience, health, and a sense of well-being.

(Add more text here to explain that this is for everyone)

item.title: About Us
item.dc:creator: anna_project3
item.content:encoded:
Mary Beth Stern, Certified MBSR Teacher

Mary Beth Stern is a Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) teacher, trained and certified by the Center for Mindfulness at UMASS Medical School. She is a Florida Board Certified Addictions counselor, and a qualified facilitator in the app-based Habit Change Programs including Eat Right Now and Unwinding Anxiety, developed by Judson Brewer, MD. She continues advanced mindfulness training at the Center for Mindfulness at Brown University. She is Level 2 MBITAC (Mindfulness- Based Intervention Teacher Assessment Criteria) trained and actively participates in several peer mentoring groups. Since 2014, she has taught throughout south Florida, offering mindfulness training at hospitals, behavioral health facilities and substance abuse treatment centers. She is currently a senior teacher for Mindful Leader, offering MBSR online and individual mindfulness coaching to an international global population.

Dr. Vanessa Miller-Curtis

Vanessa Miller-Curtis, Ph.D. has over 12 years of experience in a variety of settings. Vanessa has spent several years developing and leading educational programs in the areas of Mindfulness, Shame and Guilt, and Contemplative Psychology in prison settings, outpatient clinics, and brain injury recovery and support groups. The effectiveness of therapeutic and educational programming for anyone on their overall well-being and its use as a tool to address anger, anxiety and other mental health issues is at the core of this work. Therapeutic educational programs pertain to psychological health and well-being. The importance of therapeutic and educational programming for any human being cannot adequately be expressed. For some, this may be the first opportunity to address a lifetime of maladaptive behaviors. The changes in thoughts, emotions, and behavior as a result of continued exposure to therapeutic and educational programming often creates an intangible shift in attitudes and values. Vanessa has a strong daily Mindfulness and MBSR personal practice. She says, "engaging in Mindfulness and MBSR daily has helped shift my perspective and provide a balance in life like no other program has been able to do." Vanessa holds a Ph.D. in Cognitive Psychology from the University of California, Riverside and a Masters degree in Clinical Psychology from Chapman University.

Leila Nabors, Certified MBSR Teacher, Co-Founder

Leila Nabors, M.Ed., LPC has been in private practice as a psychotherapist for over 18 years. She has over 25 years of experience as a counselor in private practice, community mental health and public schools.  In private practice Leila became interested in Mindfulness-Based Interventions (MBI) as a therapeutic approach and Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) as a psychoeducational program to enhance healing and increase well-being. Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction is a program that uses mindfulness and meditation to help people cope more effectively with stress and illness by increasing present moment awareness.   Leila has studied with Dr. Jon Kabat-Zinn who developed Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) in the late 1970s at the University of Massachusetts Medical School.  After six years of training and practice, she received certification as a Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction teacher.   Leila is the only certified teacher in the state of Alabama and one of only a handful in the Southeast. She and Beth Cook founded the Alabama Institute for Mindfulness in 2015. 

Beth Cook, LPC,Co-Founder

Beth Cook, MS, LPC, is a psychotherapist with 30 years of experience in a variety of settings including community mental health centers, public schools, inpatient psychiatric facilities and, since 2005, private practice. In addition to a foundation in Cognitive Behavioral Therapy she has trained extensively in the areas of spiritually-oriented and mind/body therapeutic models. Throughout her career, Beth has been interested in the intersection of emotional, physical and spiritual aspects of health and wholeness and she now integrates mindfulness practice into the psychotherapeutic interventions she uses with clients. Beth has completed the 8-week Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction class and maintains a regular meditation practice. She is also a certified spiritual director who honors the wisdom found in all of the worlds enduring spiritual and religious traditions. Beth is a core faculty member of the Metagem Institute which offers training in spiritual direction and the contemplative path. In this role she teaches mindfulness as an integrative practice one which contributes to the practitioners own self-knowledge and well-being. Beth and Leila founded the Alabama Institute for Mindfulness in 2015.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: <iframe title="What Is Mindfulness - Center for Mindfulness, UMASS" width="837" height="471" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/p33800Pu2P8?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

item.title: What Is Mindfulness?
item.dc:creator: anna_project3
item.content:encoded:
It is interesting that many articles that try to define mindfulness begin with the word "simply." Phrases such as "simply" or "simply put mindfulness is are an effort to concisely express a concept, mindfulness, that has become increasingly difficult to relate to in our fast-paced stressed-out culture. Dr. Jon Kabat-Zinn defines mindfulness as the awarenesss that arises when you pay attention, in a particular way: on purpose, in the present moment, and non-judgementally.  When we talk about mindfulnesss, we mean beginning to really notice sensations in the body, thoughts and emotions coming and going, and fully taking in our experience, whatever it is, with all of our senses. This is what is meant by paying attention, in a particular way: on purpose."  

While the concept of mindfulness may be quite simple, it may not be that easy to bring the practice of mindfulness to our daily living.  So the invitation here is to begin to reengage with your life fully, by paying attention on purpose, getting off automatic pilot and opening to whatever is present in this moment. Mindfulness helps us respond to our life circumstances, whatever they are, rather than automatically reacting from the old familiar habitual patterns. And yes, that means paying attention to the difficulties we encounter too. By attending to those difficulties in this way, we may begin to see through a new lens and discover new possibilities. The difficulties probably wont disappear, but our relationship to those difficulties may be transformed. 

Practicing mindfulness might mean meditating, sitting in the yard and paying attention on purpose to the sights and sounds of nature, or it might be pausing for three or four breaths many times during the day. The following explanation of mindfulness by Sharon Salzberg emphasizes that mindfulness is not just a concept to be understood but a practice, or more precisely a way of being.

"Mindfulness isnt just about knowing that youre hearing something, seeing something, or even observing that youre having a particular feeling. Its about doing so in a certain way with balance and equanimity, and without judgment. Mindfulness is the practice of paying attention in a way that creates space for insight.

You may find the short video below from the UMass Medical School Center for Mindfulness quite informative.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: <iframe title="What Is Mindfulness - Center for Mindfulness, UMASS" width="837" height="471" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/p33800Pu2P8?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

item.title: Stress Reduction
item.dc:creator: anna_project3
item.content:encoded:
Without a doubt, stress takes a toll on all of us. It is a natural response to perceived threats or change in our world. But it is important to note that not all stress is negative.  Sometimes stress may help us perform better or even get us out of a life-threatening situation. When we experience stress a wide variety of physical and psychological symptoms or reactions may occur. If we become stuck in stress reactivity or fight or flight mode stress may manifest in ways that have negative impact on our physical and psychological well-being. 

As a society, we tend to treat stress as a natural byproduct of our fast-paced lives and something we must learn to tolerate (as in I can handle it). According to these statistics from the American Institute of Stress:

  • 77 % Percent of people regularly experience physical symptoms caused by stress
  • 73% Regularly experience psychological symptoms caused by stress
  • 33% Of people feel they are living with extreme stress
  • 48% Feel their stress has increased over the past five years
  • 76% Cited money and work as the leading cause of their stress
  • 48% Of people reported lying awake at night due to stress

Over 40 years ago, Jon Kabat-Zinn developed an 8-week stress reduction program at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center called Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR).  In this program, participants begin to learn how to skillfully work with the stressful encounters of daily living, as well as pain, illness, anxiety, depression, and other stressful situations.  MBSR is based on the principle of mindfulness, which is about waking up and being fully present for each moment of life. Participants begin to learn how to turn off the automatic pilot and become fully aware, awake and attuned to the richness of living.  Mindfulness helps us become aware of our reactivity in daily life and helps create the space for a more insightful response.   A Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction program involves the use of various forms of meditation and movement, including gentle stretching and yoga to cultivate awareness and reduce stress.

The evidence is all too clear regarding the impact of stress on our health and well-being. Stress reduction is not just about relaxing; it is about learning to skillfully navigate our ever-changing internal and external landscape. And although, at times, it may not seem like we have any control over stressors in our lives, it is important to remember, as Jon Kabat-Zinn says, It is not the stressors per se, but how you handle them which influences the short and long-term health effects they may have on your mind and your body. Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction is about cultivating inner resources and skills that help people begin to "handle" stress in a different way.

item.title: Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR)
item.dc:creator: anna_project3
item.content:encoded:
Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) is an eight-week intensive, psychoeducational program which was launched in 1979 at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center by Dr. Jon Kabat-Zinn. More than 20,000 people have completed this evidence-based program and learned to cultivate inner resources and develop skills that help them cope more effectively with stress, pain and illness. MBSR offers participants a powerful integrative approach, that when applied to everyday living can lead to health, healing and well-being.  Mindfulness is about getting off "auto pilot," waking up and being fully present in the richness of each moment of life. Present moment awareness creates a space which helps us consciously respond to life rather than reacting automatically from habit. The MBSR program utilizes meditation and mindful movement to help individuals cultivate skills, increase awareness and access innate inner resources. Mindfulness helps us develop a deep inner reservoir accessible during the inevitable stressful events encountered in life. 

According to Jon Kabat-Zinn mindfulness is "paying attention in a particular way; on purpose, in the present moment, and nonjudgmentally." It is not about "clearing" or "quieting" the mind, but it is about purposefully paying attention and bringing awareness to sensations in the body, thoughts, emotions and even the environment around you. In an MBSR class you might be asked to "sit" and notice your breath, physical sensations , sounds, thoughts or emotions. This type of attentional training helps your mind focus on the present moment. And, if you are fully present in this moment, you are much less likely to get lost in thoughts about the past or worries about the future. Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction helps you begin to turn off the automatic pilot and awaken to the fullness of your one and only life.

I am an Army Veteran with PTSD. PTSD at its core is about being stuck in the past. MBSR training teaches you a proven methodology for being and staying in the present. For the first time in 20 years I am moving forward in my life and I credit this course for making that possible."

Lisa

This class is taught by a certified MBSR teacher and is the same course offered at hospitals, medical schools, colleges/universities and other institutions around the world. MBSR is the most researched evidence-based mindfulness program in the country. Over 40 years of research has shown statistically significant improvements in symptoms associated with certain illnesses, as well as other physical and mental health. Participants in MBSR classes often report a greater sense of well-being and reduction in perceived stress. Classes are 2.5 hours in length and are held once a week for 8 weeks. Each class includes educational components, meditation, discussion and gentle movement.

In-Person

8 Week Stress Reduction Program
Tuesday evenings September 20, 2022 - November 8, 2022 from 5:30pm - 8:00pm

item.title: Unwinding Anxiety
item.dc:creator: anna_project3
item.content:encoded:
A small group app-based mindfulness training

A new, evidenced - based therapeutic intervention using a combination of a digital app on a cell phone or other device, in conjunction with weekly in-person meetings with a trained program facilitator/counselor offers 24/7 support on the spot, when you need it most.
This program, developed by Judson Brewer, MD PHD, Director of Research and Innovation at Brown University Center for Mindfulness School of Public Health is a ground- breaking, evidence-based method of habit change which engages the brains inherent, reward -based learning system. When anxiety strikes, triggering urges to react in ways that are unhealthy, whether it is to overeat, abuse substances, give in to anger or other impulses, we are usually feeling alone to battle the anxiety, overcome the urge and white knuckle the situation on our own.

With one-on-one guidance, as well as group support, we identify the triggers and behaviors and learn to short circuit the habit loop before anxiety takes over. In accordance with the latest neuroscience, change is not dependent on harsh self -discipline, but rather enlists the brain as an ally in moving toward behaviors that are intrinsically healthy and rewarding.

The Unwinding Anxiety program is a 90-minute weekly class in conjunction with the Unwinding Anxiety app which requires about 10 minutes a day. The Unwinding Anxiety website describes the app as "evidence based daily guidance designed for anyone suffering from anxiety." During the weekly classes participants will have an opportunity to further explore what they are learning about their anxiety triggers and anxiety habits. Participants will also have the opportunity in class to practice skills that help them break the cycle of worry and panic, as well as cultivate "anti-anxiety tools".

ONLINE VIA ZOOM CLASS RUNS 6 CONSECUTIVE WEEKS. Beginning Tuesday, April 12 through Tuesday, May 17, 2022
TIME: 4:30pm to 6:00pm CST (5:30pm-7:00pm EST)
TUITION: $225
APP COST: $115 (purchased separately online)
TOTAL COST: $340 or $225 (if you already have the app)

If you have questions about this program, feel free to contact Mary Beth Stern at mbfstern@gmail.com

How does unwinding anxiety work?
About Instructors

item.title: Weekly Mindfulness Sessions
item.dc:creator: anna_project3
item.content:encoded:
These are difficult times. So, let's come together and practice some stress reduction and learn some adaptive coping skills. As counterintuitive as it may seem, paying attention to the thoughts, emotions and body sensations that are arising in these scary times may actually help us manage our stress. We can be blindsided by our fears when we constantly push them away. Mindfulness practice is about paying attention to the present moment, whether we like it or not. Mindfulness doesn't change the difficult times; it gives the deep roots we need to weather the storm.

Open To All

Sunday Mindfulness Session 
Join us each Sunday of the month live via Zoom
Start your week with a 30-to-40-minute meditation practice and brief discussion. No experience is required, and all are welcome. A session may include guided meditation practice, shared experience and a brief reading or poem.
Start time is 4:00pm (sign on at 3:55)

This event is free and open to the public.

Questions? Contact mindfulalabama@gmail.com

Follow this link on Sundays

item.title: Book Study Course
item.dc:creator: anna_project3
item.content:encoded:
The Miracle of Mindfulness

Led by Dr. Vanessa Miller-Curtis

This course is about learning to apply mindfulness to our everyday lives through the teachings in The Miracle of Mindfulness. We will practice together, sit together, and reflect on and embrace the changes mindfulness can bring.

(Add more to description here)

Mindfulness is the capacity to be here, to witness deeply everything that happens in the present moment.

Thich Nhat Hanh

Thursday, April 21 through Thursday, May 26, 2022

Time: 11:30am to 1:00pm (CST)

This class will meet every Thursday for 1.5 hours a week for 6 weeks.

item.title: Mindful Sports Performance Enhancement (MSPE)
item.dc:creator: anna_project3
item.content:encoded:
This program, developed by Keith Kaufman, Carol Glass, and Timothy Pineau is an empirically based, six session mindfulness based mental training program developed for athletes. Mindful Sports Performance Enhancement is grounded in the traditions of Jon Kabat-Zinns  mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) and Segal, Williams, and Teasdales mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT). Each session has experiential, educational, discussion, and home practice elements that teach athletes the basics of mindfulness. Once basic mindfulness exercises are introduced and practiced there is a gradual segue into sport-specific mindfulness exercises. While this program consists of six sessions that are 1.5 hours in length, it can be modified to accommodate the time constraints or needs of individual athletes, performers or athletic teams. 

Although the expression the game is 90% mental is frequently heard, mental training is seldom part of an athlete's preparation. Athletes, as well as coaches, tend to focus on the physical, technical and tactical aspects of athletic performance and leave little or no time for what some have said is the most important aspect of any sports performance, the mental game. The quest for peak performance usually explores mental states like flow or being in the zone. In fact, the authors of Mindful Sports Performance Enhancement note, perhaps most exciting are apparent links between MSPE training and the achievement of flow. With MSPE, the cultivation of the mental game moves from being mostly a piecemeal approach to a systematic, empirically based program that builds on each athlete's personal experience.

Mindful Sports Performance Enhancement (MSPE) may also be helpful for individuals in the performing arts. There are many similarities in the psychology of performance between athletes and musicians, dancers and actors. MSPE can be adapted and used with performing artists in all types of high pressure environments. The mindfulness skills learned in MSPE training can be woven not only into daily living but into the experience of being human and a musician, dancer, actor or athlete. The beauty of MSPE is that it has implications far beyond the athletic field or stage. It opens the door to a way of seeing more clearly even in the midst of a sometimes chaotic life. 

This program is facilitated by Leila Nabors, M.Ed., LPC, a certified Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction teacher. Leila was a multi-sport competitive athlete in high school and college and enjoyed a 20-year teaching and coaching career. She has coached state championship high school teams and was the inaugural womens volleyball coach at the University of Alabama in Huntsville. Leila left teaching and coaching to pursue a career in counseling and psychotherapy. Working with individual athletes and teams to help them reach their full potential, for Leila, is like returning home.

About Instructors
Register

For more information or consultation regarding work with athletic programs, teams, individual athletes, or performing artists contact Leila Nabors directly at llnabors@comcast.net or 256-682-2235.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: anna_project3
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:

Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)

...or something like this:

The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.

As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!
